item.title: Example Page 1
item.description:

item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: Pakistan & CoVID-19
item.description:
DATA Description

The data set is for the Covid-19 virus affecting all the countries, categorising the cases into confirmed cases, recovered cases and cases that resulted in death. The data set has a lot of limited variables. The data is collected from this link here. Our primary focus for the effected country will be Pakistan. (???)

Why Pakistan?

Pakistan, officially the Islamic Republic of Pakistan, is a country in South Asia. It is the world’s fifth-most populous country with a population exceeding 212.2 million. It is the 33rd-largest country by area, spanning 881,913 square kilometres (340,509 square miles).

As the worlds 5th largest populated country, the government of Pakistan had a very different approach in how to handle, and contain the virus.

First the government was hesitent in imposing the lockdown. As reported by this article here.

Then the government with pressure from the opposition international community and the people imposed the lockdown as described in this article.

Here are some important dates according this source.

Methodology

We will start by filtering the loaded data, the country we want is Pakistan, so we will be filtering that. The first case in Pakistan was reported in February, so let’s get rid of additional dates. Some variables will be taken out, the province variable is empty, coordinates like latitude and longitude make no sense as all the recorded cases are from the same coordinates.

With the lockdown lifted during important events there were a lot of reservations. Some important dates are

13th of March (lockdown imposed)

27th of March (Eid-ul-Fitr, a one day religious festival)

24th of May (Smart lockdown imposed, only affected areas under lockdown)

31st of July (Eid-ul-Adha, a three day religions festival)

8th of August (lockdown lifted)

14th of August (Independence Day)

The table is interactive, for users to do their own research with respect to day, month, week of the year, number of cases reported, deaths reported, patients recovered. To identify the surge in numbers, especially after the above mentioned dates.

Confirmed Death Recovered
Min. : 1 Min. : 0.00 Min. : -8
1st Qu.: 340 1st Qu.: 7.00 1st Qu.: 90
Median : 1013 Median : 23.00 Median : 676
Mean : 1730 Mean : 36.81 Mean : 1641
3rd Qu.: 2721 3rd Qu.: 60.00 3rd Qu.: 2060
Max. :12073 Max. :178.00 Max. :19772

Confirmed Summary Summarising Pakistan’s COVID19 cases, in confirmed cases, in a day the least number of cases that were reported is 1 and the maximum number of cases reported in a day are 12,073. The average number of confirmed cases throughout the period have been 1,730. From a range perspective, 1,013 has been the middle for reported cases in a day.

The first quartile (Q1) tells us the middle value from the smallest value which in this case is 1 and the median 1,013. In other words, the first 25% of the cases are reported lower than 340.

The third Quartile (Q3) tells us the middle value from the largest value which in this case is 12,073 and the median 1,013. In other words, the last 25% of the cases are reported higher than 2,721.

Death Summary

Summarising Pakistan’s deaths reported due to COVID19, in deaths reported the least number of deaths reported is 0 on a day, and the maximum number of deaths reported on a day is 178. The average deaths or the mean of deaths reported throughout the period is 36. The mid-range on the number of deaths is at 23.

The first quartile (Q1) tells us the middle value from the smallest value which in this case is 0 and the median 23. In other words, the first 25% of the deaths reported are lower than 7.

The third Quartile (Q3) tells us the middle value from the largest value which in this case is 178 and the median 23. In other words, the last 25% of the cases are reported higher than 60.

Recovered Summary

Summarizing the recovered COVID19 cases in Pakistan. The least number of recovered cases are a bit different, the least number of patients that recovered in a day are -8 which means that the cases reported were untrue, follow this link to get a better understand of the interpretation. The maximum number of recovered cases reported in a day are 19,772. The average recovery of covid19 patients recovered throughout the period is 1,641.

The first quartile (Q1) tells us the middle value from the smallest value which in this case is -8 and the median 676. In other words, the first 25% of the deaths reported are lower than 90.

The third Quartile (Q3) tells us the middle value from the largest value which in this case is 19,772 and the median 676. In other words, the last 25% of the cases are reported higher than 2,060.

item.title: Pakistan & CoVID-19
item.description:
DATA Description

The data set is for the Covid-19 virus affecting all the countries, categorising the cases into confirmed cases, recovered cases and cases that resulted in death. The data set has a lot of limited variables. The data is collected from this link here. Our primary focus for the effected country will be Pakistan. @RamiKrispin

Why Pakistan?

Pakistan, officially the Islamic Republic of Pakistan, is a country in South Asia. It is the world’s fifth-most populous country with a population exceeding 212.2 million. It is the 33rd-largest country by area, spanning 881,913 square kilometres (340,509 square miles).

As the worlds 5th largest populated country, the government of Pakistan had a very different approach in how to handle, and contain the virus.

First the government was hesitent in imposing the lockdown. As reported by this article here.

Then the government with pressure from the opposition international community and the people imposed the lockdown as described in this article.

Here are some important dates according this source.

Methodology

We will start by filtering the loaded data, the country we want is Pakistan, so we will be filtering that. The first case in Pakistan was reported in February, so let’s get rid of additional dates. Some variables will be taken out, the province variable is empty, coordinates like latitude and longitude make no sense as all the recorded cases are from the same coordinates.

13th of March (lockdown imposed)

27th of March (Eid-ul-Fitr, a one day religious festival)

31st of July (Eid-ul-Adha, a three day religions festival)

Median : 1013 Median : 23.00 Median : 676
Mean : 1730 Mean : 36.81 Mean : 1641
3rd Qu.: 2721 3rd Qu.: 60.00 3rd Qu.: 2060
Max. :12073 Max. :178.00 Max. :19772

Confirmed Summary Summarising Pakistan’s COVID19 cases, in confirmed cases, in a day the least number of cases that were reported is 1 and the maximum number of cases reported in a day are 12,073. The average number of confirmed cases throughout the period have been 1,730. From a range perspective, 1,013 has been the middle for reported cases in a day.

item.title: Romania & CoVID-19
item.description:
c19 <- read.csv("owid-covid-data.csv")

DATA Description

The data sets used are of the COVID-19 virus, containing data on all countries. The first data set contains the total cases, new cases, cases per million of the countries population, total deaths, new deaths, new tests, total tests and stingency index. The data set has extensive variables, however, not all are used in this blog. The data set was obtained form here. The first set although extensive, did not conatin the varaible of cases recovered. A second data set was used to obtain the cases recovered from here.

Why Romania?

Romania <- c19 %>% filter(location == "Romania") %>% 
  select(-iso_code, 
         -continent, 
         -location) %>% 
  filter(date >     "2020-02-26") %>% mutate(date = as.Date(date))
Romi <- c19 %>% filter(location == "Romania") %>% 
  select( date, new_cases, new_tests) %>% 
  filter(date >     "2020-02-29")  %>% mutate(Month = month(date,label = TRUE,abbr = FALSE)) %>% na.omit() 
rp <- Romi %>% ggplot( aes(x= new_tests, 
                           y = new_cases, 
                           color = Month)) + 
  geom_point() # + facet_wrap(~ month(date)) + geom_smooth()
rp2 <- rp + facet_wrap(~ Month) 
ggplotly(rp)
tab<- Romania %>% select(date, total_cases, new_cases,new_cases_per_million, total_deaths, new_deaths,new_tests, total_tests, stringency_index) %>% na.omit() %>% filter(date <     "2020-03-18")%>% kable( ) %>% kable_styling(full_width = NULL,
  position = "center",
  font_size = NULL,
  row_label_position = "l",
  repeat_header_continued = FALSE,
  stripe_color = "black",
  stripe_index = NULL,
  table.envir = "table",
  fixed_thead = FALSE)
tab
date total_cases new_cases new_cases_per_million total_deaths new_deaths new_tests total_tests stringency_index
2020-03-13 64 19 0.988 0 0 624 2545 58.33
2020-03-14 89 25 1.300 0 0 384 2929 58.33
2020-03-15 113 24 1.248 0 0 276 3205 58.33
2020-03-16 139 26 1.352 0 0 503 3708 58.33
2020-03-17 184 45 2.339 0 0 442 4150 58.33

Methodology

item.title: An example preprint / working paper
item.description:
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic

Academic | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation

item.title: An example journal article

Click the Cite button above to demo the feature to enable visitors to import publication metadata into their reference management software.
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.
